raw_results.original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. For example, mouse coat color ranges from white to red to brown to black (Hou et al., [@B9]; Lathrop et al., [@B12]). Among vertebrates, the pattern of hair types in birds is relatively distinct, often falling into three primary categories; down coat (hairless), bristles (feathered) and plumes (feathered). The number and distribution of plumes may be consistent in populations or highly varied across one individual or species (Lathrop and Alberts, [@B11]; Lathrop et al., [@B13], [@B12]).

This has been an emerging trend in the politics of the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s and is almost always the case in Germany on national and state level, and in most constituencies at the communal level. Furthermore, since the forming of the Republic of Iceland there has never been a government not led by a coalition (usually of the Independence Party and one other (often the Social Democratic Alliance). raw_results.sampled:
More commonly, in cases where there are three or more parties, no one party is likely to gain power alone, and parties work with each other to win control over specific policy spaces. A set of conditions arise from this multi-party system which create conditions in which a given party may dominate the system. This domination may take the form of an "electoralist equilibrium," which assumes that both government policy and domestic economic policy are made by a coalition of parties, and each party makes commitments in exchange for coalition membership. In other words, coalition government leads to the development of power incentives and strategies for parties, both inside and outside the government, so that they are each compelled to develop commitments to act in ways that further their own power within the coalition. This is not a stable state of affairs in and of itself—other types of political system, such as a parliamentary system or pure representative democracy, will tend to be more stable in their own ways.

raw_results.original: The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own agenda. Darwin distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, hoping that suitable applicants would come forward, as translators were expected to make their own arrangements with a local publisher. He welcomed the distinguished elderly naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn, but the German translation published in 1860 imposed Bronn's own ideas, adding controversial themes that Darwin had deliberately omitted. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races", and added essays on issues including the origin of life, as well as a final chapter on religious implications partly inspired by Bronn's adherence to Naturphilosophie. In 1862, Bronn produced a second edition based on the third English edition and Darwin's suggested additions, but then died of a heart attack. Darwin corresponded

Vladimir had been prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972. He was forced to flee to Scandinavia in 983, where he married a Norwegian woman named Sunniva and established a new dynasty there, the House of Monigais; he would rule in Novgorod as a vassal of the Kingdom of Denmark. He is not to be confused with his uncle Sviatoslav II of Kiev.

raw_results.original: Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-concept, identity represents a coherent sense of self stable across circumstances and including past experiences and future goals. Everyone has a self-concept, whereas Erik Erikson argued that not everyone fully achieves identity. Erikson's theory of stages of development includes the identity crisis in which adolescents must explore different possibilities and integrate different parts of themselves before committing to their beliefs. He described the resolution of this process as a stage of "identity achievement" but also stressed that the identity challenge "is never fully resolved once and for all at one point in time". raw_results.original: Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine and subsequently asked them how they felt. Interestingly, Marañón found that most of these patients felt something but in the absence of an actual emotion-evoking stimulus, the patients were unable to interpret their physiological arousal as an experienced emotion. Schachter did agree that physiological reactions played a big role in emotions. He suggested that physiological reactions contributed to emotional experience by facilitating a focused cognitive appraisal of a given physiologically arousing event and that this appraisal was what defined the subjective emotional experience. Emotions were thus a result of two-stage process: general physiological arousal, and experience of emotion. For example, the physiological arousal, heart pounding, in a response to an evoking stimulus, the sight of a bear in the kitchen. Tech media website CNET gave new Super Slim 4 out of 5 stars ("Excellent"), saying "The Super Slim PlayStation 3 shrinks a powerful gaming machine into a svelte shape that is nearly impossible to get into an entertainment center. It's an extremely satisfying gaming experience for one reason: PlayStation 3 has a lot going for it."

On a similar note, the site's editors went on to say "There's much to like about this smaller machine, and it's very easy to recommend the new Super Slim to anyone who doesn't feel like fitting one in their entertainment center."

"This is the slimmest PlayStation 3 yet, making the machine smaller, lighter, and easier to access," they added.

raw_results.original: Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these male line ancestors appear to have been mainly Middle Eastern. For example, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than with non-Jewish populations in areas where Jews lived in Eastern Europe, Germany and the French Rhine Valley. This is consistent with Jewish traditions in placing most Jewish paternal origins in the region of the Middle East. Conversely, the maternal lineages of Jewish populations, studied by looking at mitochondrial DNA, are generally more heterogeneous. Scholars such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk believe this indicates that many Jewish males found new mates from European and other communities in the places where they migrated in the diaspora after fleeing ancient Israel.
perturbed_original: Y DNA studies generally imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. That is, for many Jewish populations, these lineages of paternal ancestors appear to have been mainly Middle Eastern. For example, Ashkenazi Jews do share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern populations than with non-Jewish populations in areas where Jews lived in Eastern Europe, such as the French Rhine Valley. This is consistent with Jewish traditions in placing most Jewish paternal origins in the region of the Old Testament. Conversely, maternal lineages of Jewish males, studied by looking at mitochondrial DNA, are generally more heterogeneous. Scholars such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk believe this indicates that many Jewish males found new mates from European and other communities in the places where they migrated in the diaspora after fleeing ancient Israel.

raw_results.sampled: The state united behind the Plan of Ayutla and ratified the new constitution in 1855. The state was able to survive through the Reform War with less damage than neighboring Veracruz, although a good third of the city's population was displaced, and most of its commerce, industry, and government were also gone. The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic distinction within Bermudians between Afro-Bermudians, Indo-Bermudians, and 'Caucasoid' Bermudians and this obscures the historic relationships of these groups. To determine the true ancestral origins of today's Bermudians, the proportion of African, American Indian, Indo-Eurasian, and 'Caucasoid' ancestry were estimated, and compared with data on genealogical ancestry in the national census over that time period.

raw_results.sampled:
Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as urates of uric acid (UA). Birds are quite different from mammals in their biology, but also in their kidney anatomy. Birds have well-developed and lobular kidneys ([Figure 1](#pbio-0020101-g001){ref-type="fig"}A). Both kidneys extract and process urine, but each of them does so independently. However, the functions of the lobular kidney have not been well defined. Traditionally, these functions were assumed to be related to excretion of UA, but the fact that UA must be removed by a uricotelic mechanism had prevented studies of the metabolic activity of the lobular kidneys. Consequently, the precise physiological functions of the lobular kidney remained largely undefined.

(A) Kid

raw_results.sampled:
Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, privilege and precedence.

Industry pundits have often called attention to the Mac's relatively small market share to predict Apple's impending doom, particularly in the early and mid-1990s when the company's future seemed bleakest. Others argue that market share is the wrong way to judge the Mac's success. Apple has positioned the Mac as a higher-end personal computer, and so it may be misleading to compare it to a budget PC. Because the overall market for personal computers has grown rapidly, the Mac's increasing sales numbers are effectively swamped by the industry's expanding sales volume as a whole. True predators do not feed directly on the prey at all. Instead, they feed on the nutrients of the prey, namely nitrogen, phosphorus and energy in their tissues. True predators are not typically food chains, since the food chain implies the food as the prey.
The true predators in the animal kingdom, for example, and in the plant kingdom, prey mainly on smaller, land-based or sea-based, animals. In the animal kingdom, true predators may be seen to also prey on other plants. These true predators then eat the prey plant , which becomes the food for the animal"

perturbed_original: A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and consumes another living thing. Whereas the other forms of predator all harm their prey in some way, this form kills them. Predators may hunt actively for prey in order to harm it, or sit and wait for prey to approach within striking distance, as in ambush predators. Some predators kill their prey and dismember or devour it prior to eating it, such as a shark or a human; others may eat their (usually much smaller) prey whole, as does a cat swallowing a fish, or a snake, duck or stork swallowing a fly. Some animals that are both large- and small prey for their size (domestic cats and dogs are prime examples) may eat with different degrees of success depending upon the circumstances; either would devour a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation entails venom that subdues a prey creature before the predator ingests the prey by itself, such as the box jellyfish

raw_results.original: The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, the Speaker of the Senate will read to the chamber a notice from the secretary to the governor general indicating when the viceroy or a deputy thereof will arrive. The Senate thereafter cannot adjourn until after the ceremony. The speaker moves to sit beside the throne, the Mace Bearer, with mace in hand, stands adjacent to him or her, and the governor general enters to take the speaker's chair. The Usher of the Black Rod is then commanded by the speaker to summon the Members of Parliament, who follow Black Rod back to the Senate, the Sergeant-at-Arms carrying the mace of the House of Commons. In the Senate, those from the commons stand behind the bar, while Black Rod proceeds to stand next to the governor general, who then nods his or her head to signify Royal Assent to the presented bills (which do not include appropriations bills). Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia is Europe's most dynamic small economy, and in recent years it has had the fastest economic growth of any European country as well as having the highest real estate and stock market valuations. The economy was hit hard and growth is on the way down a bit even as other nations are on the upswing. Economic news keeps getting worse, and the economy is only at about 8.5% for the year now -- the lowest of any country in 2008 -- and the government is looking at a large budget deficit (more on that to come).

A bit further north, Latvia is also taking a bit of a hit, as its own debt crisis has caused it to cut back on economic growth to more normal levels. The economy grew less than 2% in 2008, and the country will probably see a 5% growth rate in 2009.

raw_results.original: The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", they were not just military expeditions but migrations of entire peoples into the empire. Such movements were aided by the refusal of the western Roman elites to support the army or pay the taxes that would have allowed the military to suppress the migration. The emperors of the 5th century were often controlled by military strongmen such as Stilicho (d. 408), Aspar (d. 471), Ricimer (d. 472), or Gundobad (d. 516), who were partly or fully of non-Roman background. When the line of western emperors ceased, many of the kings who replaced them were from the same background. Intermarriage between the new kings and the Roman elites was common. This led to a fusion of Roman culture with the customs of the invading tribes, including the popular assemblies that allowed free male tribal members more say in political matters

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (mainly Spain, Italy, Portugal, Greece and Turkey) universities shared a common pattern of "socialist" and "individualist" orientation in terms of their student culture, their student councils, the curricula of their higher institutions of learning, and in particular, the teaching methodologies.

Socialist orientation
The universities in northern Europe developed as autonomous higher learning institutions, which meant that they grew up alongside the professional associations that they served, with those academic personnel who were not on the staff of the professional associations being in effect employees of the educational institutions to which they had been assigned. This pattern was not typical of the institutions of higher learning in southern Europe. In terms of their student culture, northern European universities developed into social organizations in which the students were active participants responsible for the content, design and general direction of the student culture.

Initially, the Turkish Cypriots favoured the continuation of the British rule. However, they were alarmed by the Greek Cypriot calls for enosis on March 25, 1962. On March 26, 1963, they passed and annulled the Cyprus Union Treaty on the grounds that it was unconstitutional. The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced new ways of thinking about the natural world. Before that time, most people—including scientists—believed that there was little difference between living things, and that all the individuals of a particular species were roughly the same. The new science of the time—which emphasized observation, prediction, and empiricism—required that any differences in animals be put down to variations in external, rather than internal, conditions. Because these external conditions are observable, and because they appear to be stable, they might be changed; the animals' difference in nature could therefore be explained and changed through intervention. For this it was necessary that some individuals should be separated into an order that could be observed systematically, and then treated differently. In Europe and the U.S. green is sometimes associated with death (green has several seemingly contrary associations), sickness, or the devil, but in China its associations are very positive, as the symbol of fertility and happiness. In the Middle Ages and Renaissance, when the color of clothing showed the owner's social status, green was worn by merchants, bankers and the gentry, while red was the color of the nobility. The Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci wears green, showing she is not from a noble family; the benches in the British House of Commons are green, while those in the House of Lords are red. The color green is the strongest predictor of the "beautiful" response in surveys. raw_results.original: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a marker that imposes restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people are ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary will also impose restrictions on the people it has included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. An example of this is the use of a particular language by a newcomer in a room full of people speaking various languages. Some people may understand the language used by this person while others may not. Those who do not understand it might take the newcomer's use of this particular language merely as a neutral sign of identity. But they might also perceive it as imposing an exclusive boundary that is meant to mark them off from her. On the other hand, those who do understand the newcomer's language

raw_results.original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

This is accomplished by using one of the two- or three-gang feeder arrangements as shown in Figure 5-6. A feeder section is isolated from other sections by using two or more switches controlled by a master switch.

Because most high-voltage feeders are designed for 120/240V systems, the three-gang system in the drawing has ground, neutral, and two hots. You don't have to mess around with all those terminals. Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the War Department's Legionnaires' program on June 30 1941.

The Legion was designed specifically to protect members of the U.S. armed forces, and members were required to prove that they would serve in the military before admission into the Legion. Members could not hold down civilian jobs at any time, and were barred from selling or receiving commissions on real estate. In December 1942, Congress passed the "Forbidden Zone Act" to limit the size of the Legion. In 1948, Congress passed the National Defense Act which gave the government the authority to remove or expel members of the Legion if they broke any laws and also changed the eligibility requirements to read: "who, while serving as a member of the Loyal Legion of the United States, the Marine Corps, or the Coast Guard, shall have voluntarily or involuntarily engaged in unauthorized activity."

Owls may hunt by sound, and many species are able to locate prey by sound alone. Sound is generally effective for large prey such as owls and bats because of this, and is an effective hunting technique in all types of environment where movement is limited by the terrain. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike first and turned his army's sights from the English Channel to the Rhine. His basic objective was to destroy the isolated Austrian armies in Southern Germany before their Russian allies could arrive. On 25 September, after great secrecy and feverish marching, 200,000 French troops began to cross the Rhine on a front of 260 km (160 mi). Austrian commander Karl Mack had gathered the greater part of the Austrian army at the fortress of Ulm in Swabia. Napoleon swung his forces to the southeast and the Grande Armée performed an elaborate wheeling movement that outflanked the Austrian positions. The Ulm Maneuver completely surprised General Mack, who belatedly understood that his army had been cut off. After some minor engagements that culminated in the Battle of Ulm, Mack finally surrendered after realizing that there was no way to break out of the French encirclement.

raw_results.original: Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that dates to 8700 BC. There is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) were the only metals used by humans before copper. Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these were typically printed right to left over more than one line on a page. For example, in Chinese typewriters, the comma is placed between the numeral 2 and the decimal point on paper, the decimal point is placed on the second line, and the decimal point on the fourth line. The Chinese are therefore accustomed to reading the text on paper starting from the right. (In this respect, the comma is analogous to ‘\’ in a text file.) Note that the right edge of the paper in a typewriter is almost always offset so that the last character printed will always be in the leftmost position. A standard page of typewritten text would therefore look something like:

12345678901234567890

Commas are therefore printed on the top line, ‘2’ on the next line

raw_results.original: Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase , gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the sight, thought and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex. Taste and smell stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata. After this it is routed through the vagus nerve and release of acetylcholine. Gastric secretion at this phase rises to 40% of maximum rate. Acidity in the stomach is not buffered by food at this point and thus acts to inhibit parietal (secretes acid) and G cell (secretes gastrin) activity via D cell secretion of somatostatin. Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem - its buildings are part of the compound called Supreme Court Building.

The Supreme Court is made up of seven judges, six of them men and one woman. A Judge of the Supreme Court is the second highest position in the system of courts within Israel. He is a judge appointed by the Prime Minister. He can be appointed on nomination only, if this nomination is accepted by approval of Shirei Tzedek.

Israeli Supreme Court judges are not subject to the control of the Knesset or any other legislative institution which may be controlled by political parties. The Supreme Court is therefore an independent institution. Its judgments are considered to be final; even a new decision handed down by a higher court cannot revoke a judgment by the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court is considered the highest court, despite being subordinate to the High Court of Justice

However, all of these facets of medieval university life are considered by standard scholarship to be independent medieval European developments with no tracable Islamic influence. Generally, the Arab Empire is seen as contributing nothing to the development of modern science (the case is rather different in medicine), and medieval scholasticism is considered to be an Arab invention. As the famous Oxford history professor Peter Laslett has argued, the twelfth and thirteenth centuries were "the age of the Renaissance."

If a predator overhunts its prey, the prey population will lower to numbers that are too scarce for the predators to find. This will cause the predator population to dip, decreasing the predation pressure on the prey population. The other usage refers to a language that is socially subordinated to a regional or national standard language, often historically cognate or related to the standard language, which is referred to as the base language. The most important languages within this term are Mandarin Chinese, Spanish, English, and Portuguese. However, the term is often used to describe languages which are not primarily part of a minority, though such languages may be used by a smaller ethnic group. The educational system is comprehensive, covering all aspects of human development beginning with children before their first birthday, which is considered to be the preschool level, progressing through the middle and high school grades, where learning skills and the core subjects are covered, and culminating at the university level.

perturbed_original: Israel has a school life expectancy of 15.5 years and a literacy rate of 97.1% according to the United Nations. The State Education Law, passed in 1953, established five types of schools including the state secular, state religious, ultra orthodox, communal settlement schools, and Arab schools. The public secular school system is the largest school group, and is attended by the majority of Jewish and non-Arab pupils in Israel. Most Arabs send their children to schools where Arabic is the language of instruction. Education is compulsory in Israel for children between the age of three and eighteen. Schooling is divided into three tiers – elementary school (grades 3–8), middle school (grades 9–10), and high school (grades 10–12) – culminating with Bagrut matriculation exams. Proficiency in core subjects such as mathematics, the Hebrew language, Hebrew and general literature, the English language, geography, Biblical scripture and civics is necessary to receive an Israeli high school certificate.
